docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on balancing professional courtesy with personal principles.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on balancing professional courtesy with personal principles.
docs.lead_paragraph: I was recently recruited to another company for a better opportunity. A partner at my former firm offered to meet me near my new job and take me to lunch as a token of gratitude for my work there; he also wanted my headhunter contacts, as he’s looking to make a move himself. While we were eating, I mentioned that most of my new team, including my boss, are women, and that both the dynamic and work-life balance were better than the former firm. He responded with “This may sound sexist, but … ” and continued on to make a disparaging remark about women.

headline.main: A Sexist Colleague Wants My Help Networking. Can I Say No?

docs.abstract: Readers discuss the sudden settlement of the Fox-Dominion litigation. Also: Migrant child labor; term limits for Congress; Korea and Japan.
docs.snippet: Readers discuss the sudden settlement of the Fox-Dominion litigation. Also: Migrant child labor; term limits for Congress; Korea and Japan.

docs.abstract: Her 2005 book, “Mozart in the Jungle,” lived up to its subtitle, “Sex, Drugs, and Classical Music,” and was later made into an Amazon TV series.
docs.snippet: Her 2005 book, “Mozart in the Jungle,” lived up to its subtitle, “Sex, Drugs, and Classical Music,” and was later made into an Amazon TV series.
docs.lead_paragraph: Blair Tindall, a freelance oboist and journalist who drew on both of those abilities to write “Mozart in the Jungle: Sex, Drugs, and Classical Music,” an eyebrow-raising 2005 memoir that became an award-winning television series, died on April 12 in Los Angeles. She was 63.

headline.main: Blair Tindall, Whose Music Memoir Scandalized, Dies at 63

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Mozart in the Jungle: Sex, Drugs, and Classical Music (Book)

docs.abstract: Toasted walnuts and sautéed kale add texture and dimension to a weeknight staple.
docs.snippet: Toasted walnuts and sautéed kale add texture and dimension to a weeknight staple.
docs.lead_paragraph: I know this space is primarily about cooking, but when The Times publishes Pete Wells’s ranked list of the top 100 restaurants in New York, it’s time to eat out! The list, he writes, creates a composite portrait of the city “that captures the diversity and character of dining in New York.” Did he miss any of your favorites? You can let me know at hellomelissa@nytimes.com.

docs.abstract: Imagining a different future can help motivate you, experts say.
docs.snippet: Imagining a different future can help motivate you, experts say.
docs.lead_paragraph: Years ago, as a young business reporter, I interviewed an advertising executive who ran a fast-food chain account. I was there to ask about the latest campaign. But when I sat down, he wanted to talk about writing fiction. He spent hours meeting with clients and crafting slogans, but he dreamed of being a novelist instead.

headline.main: Want to Make a Change? Conjure Your ‘Possible Selves.’

docs.abstract: What would you do for a Taylor Swift sweatshirt? Outside a stadium in Tampa, hundreds of fans waited overnight in the rain before scrambling for Eras Tour merch.
docs.snippet: What would you do for a Taylor Swift sweatshirt? Outside a stadium in Tampa, hundreds of fans waited overnight in the rain before scrambling for Eras Tour merch.
docs.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Did you hear about the women who hid all night underneath the truck?

docs.abstract: Even without a trial, the Dominion suit made plain that the network’s main goal is the maintenance of a reality bubble.
docs.snippet: Even without a trial, the Dominion suit made plain that the network’s main goal is the maintenance of a reality bubble.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Fox News reached a settlement in the Dominion Voting Systems defamation suit over the spread of election disinformation. For $787.5 million, Fox bought its way out of the embarrassing — or, depending where you sit, satisfying — prospect of its anchors, its executives and its founding chief, Rupert Murdoch, taking the stand.

headline.main: Everybody Knows What Fox News Is Now

docs.abstract: The largest public sector union in Canada went on strike on Wednesday over wages and return to office rules, causing delays to border crossings and passport and income tax services.
docs.snippet: The largest public sector union in Canada went on strike on Wednesday over wages and return to office rules, causing delays to border crossings and passport and income tax services.
docs.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canadians faced a variety of delays and disruptions on Wednesday after the largest union representing federal government workers went on strike over a variety of contract issues, including wages and remote work.

headline.main: Canada’s Federal Workers Strike, Disrupting Government Services

docs.abstract: The election technology company has several more defamation lawsuits pending against public figures and news outlets.
docs.snippet: The election technology company has several more defamation lawsuits pending against public figures and news outlets.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dominion Voting Systems did more on Tuesday than settle its lawsuit against Fox News for $787.5 million: It also set the tone for the many related defamation cases it has filed.

headline.main: What’s Next for Dominion After Its $787.5 Million Settlement With Fox News?

docs.abstract: The author of “Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret” received the D.H. Lawrence novel after her wedding in 1959: “The marriage didn’t last but the honeymoon was memorable.”
docs.snippet: The author of “Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret” received the D.H. Lawrence novel after her wedding in 1959: “The marriage didn’t last but the honeymoon was memorable.”
docs.lead_paragraph: My night stand is a mess. There are always books piled up, sometimes spilling onto the floor. I’m about to start Rebecca Makkai’s “I Have Some Questions for You.” I just finished “Still Pictures,” by Janet Malcolm. My daughter recently recommended “Roses, in the Mouth of a Lion,” by Bushra Rehman. Yesterday afternoon I read a graphic memoir, “Gender Queer,” by Maia Kobabe, the most banned book in the country right now. I found it moving and enlightening. Books I’ve finished but still in the pile: “Ms. Demeanor,” by Elinor Lipman, because I never miss one of her funny, delightful novels. “The Light Pirate,” by Lily Brooks Dalton, a book I can’t stop thinking about so I have to go back and read parts of it again.

headline.main: The Best Book Judy Blume Ever Got as a Gift? ‘Lady Chatterley’s Lover.’
